body.p: The swift utility (or CLI) is installed on the lifecycle manager node and also on all other nodes running the Swift proxy service. To use this utility, set the following environment variables:
body.note: You do not need to be the root user.
body.p: You must enter the appropriate password for the demo user and select the correct endpoint for the OS_AUTH_URL value. You can then examine the following account data:$ swift stat Account: AUTH_205804d000a242d385b8124188284998 Containers: 0 Objects: 0 Bytes: 0 X-Put-Timestamp: 1442249536.31989 Connection: keep-alive X-Timestamp: 1442249536.31989 X-Trans-Id: tx5493faa15be44efeac2e6-0055f6fb3f Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
In the above example, there are no containers. Execute the following command and create a container:swift post documents

The newly created container appears. But there are no objects:$ swift stat documents Account: AUTH_205804d000a242d385b8124188284998 Container: documents Objects: 0 Bytes: 0 Read ACL: Write ACL: Sync To: Sync Key: Accept-Ranges: bytes X-Storage-Policy: General Connection: keep-alive X-Timestamp: 1442249637.69486 X-Trans-Id: tx1f59d5f7750f4ae8a3929-0055f6fbcc Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Upload a document:$ swift upload documents mydocument mydocument
List objects in the container:$ swift list documents mydocument

p.note: This is a brief introduction to the swift CLI. Use --help command for more information.
